description: The halo mass function now takes a halo dataset that has been loaded rather than reading in halo finding outputs that had been written to a text file.  Passing a halo dataset to HaloMassFunction now assumes that the user wants to create the halo mass function for those simulated halos, and only creates the analytic mass function if told to do so and given appropriate arguments.  The analytic function can also be created if a halo dataset is not provided.  A few other parts of the code have also been cleaned up, and the creation of the analytic halo mass function now uses the new units quantities rather than old physical constants that are no longer part of yt.  The names of the arrays hanging off the HaloMassFcn object have been updated to be more representative of what they actually are.  "Haloes" has been changed to "halos" to be more consistent with the rest of yt.
title: Cleaning up the halo mass function

content.raw:
I've updated a bunch of the narrative docs, the docstrings, and the mass function code itself.  It's quite a bit more robust now, and returns arrays with yt units attached.  

I took a stab at making a simple test for the halo mass function, but the success of that is highly doubtful, at best.
content.html:
I've updated a bunch of the narrative docs, the docstrings, and the mass function code itself. It's quite a bit more robust now, and returns arrays with yt units attached.

I took a stab at making a simple test for the halo mass function, but the success of that is highly doubtful, at best.

pullrequest.title: Cleaning up the halo mass function

content.raw:
Hey @bcrosby, the tests look fine to me.  I tried to run the example in the docs and got a an error.  It looks like a small thing.
I ran this: http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4526/

and got

```
#!python

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 5, in <module>
    log_mass_min=5, log_mass_max=9, fitting_function=5)
  File "/Users/britton/Documents/work/yt/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/analysis_modules/halo_mass_function/halo_mass_function.py", line 232, in __init__
    hmf.unit_registry = UnitRegistry()
NameError: global name 'UnitRegistry' is not defined
```

My only other comment is that right now it seems that the ``write_out`` functions writes different data columns for the analytic and dataset mass functions.  This is the original behavior and not you're doing, but I think it would make sense to change this so that they both write out the same data.  On that note, it also looks like some of the data written out has units of Mpc^-3, while other columns have units of (Mpc/h)^-3.  I think it would be better to just have one unit system.

Other than these comments and some small stuff below, this looks great.  Thanks for working on this!
content.html:
Hey Brian Crosby, the tests look fine to me. I tried to run the example in the docs and got a an error. It looks like a small thing. I ran this: http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4526/

and got

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 5, in <module>
    log_mass_min=5, log_mass_max=9, fitting_function=5)
  File "/Users/britton/Documents/work/yt/yt-x86_64/src/yt-hg/yt/analysis_modules/halo_mass_function/halo_mass_function.py", line 232, in __init__
    hmf.unit_registry = UnitRegistry()
NameError: global name 'UnitRegistry' is not defined

My only other comment is that right now it seems that the write_out functions writes different data columns for the analytic and dataset mass functions. This is the original behavior and not you're doing, but I think it would make sense to change this so that they both write out the same data. On that note, it also looks like some of the data written out has units of Mpc^-3, while other columns have units of (Mpc/h)^-3. I think it would be better to just have one unit system.

Other than these comments and some small stuff below, this looks great. Thanks for working on this!

content.raw: The two asterisks only on one side of the key word makes this render a bit strange.  Could you do something like put two on the other side as well, which should make the keyword show up as bold.  Does anyone know if there is a better standard that we should be following in places like this?
content.html: The two asterisks only on one side of the key word makes this render a bit strange. Could you do something like put two on the other side as well, which should make the keyword show up as bold. Does anyone know if there is a better standard that we should be following in places like this?
